title: 7. Maximum Subarray

children.text: , find the contiguous subarray (containing at least one number) which has the largest sum and return its sum.

starter_code.RUBY:
def max_sub_array(nums)
  # Write your solution here
  0
end

solution.RUBY:
def max_sub_array(nums)
  max_sum = nums[0]
  current_sum = nums[0]
  
  (1...nums.length).each do |i|
    current_sum = [nums[i], current_sum + nums[i]].max
    max_sum = [max_sum, current_sum].max
  end
  
  max_sum
end
solution.PYTHON:
def max_sub_array(nums):
  max_sum = nums[0]
  current_sum = nums[0]
  
  for i in range(1, len(nums)):
    current_sum = max(nums[i], current_sum + nums[i])
    max_sum = max(max_sum, current_sum)
    
  return max_sum

hints: If you've figured out the O(n) solution, try coding another solution using the divide and conquer approach
Keep track of the current sum and the maximum sum found so far

children.text: Find the contiguous subarray with the largest sum in an integer array.
Use Kadane's algorithm: at each position, decide whether to extend the current subarray or start a new one.
Iterate through the array, keeping track of the current sum and the maximum sum found so far.
Maximum subarray is at the start or end
Start new subarray if sum drops below current element

    numsStr := input[:commaPos]
    targetStr := input[commaPos+1:]

    }

}

title: 4. Reverse Linked List

children.text: Given the head of a singly linked list, reverse the list, and return the new head.
You must reverse the list in-place.
The number of nodes in the list is in the range [0, 5000]

starter_code.RUBY:
def reverse_list(head)
  # Write your solution here
  nil
end

solution.RUBY:
def reverse_list(head)
  prev = nil
  current = head
  
  while current
    next_temp = current.next
    current.next = prev
    prev = current
    current = next_temp
  end
  
  prev
end
solution.PYTHON:
def reverse_list(head):
    prev = None
    current = head
    
    while current:
        next_temp = current.next
        current.next = prev
        prev = current
        current = next_temp
        
    return prev

hints: Use a temporary variable to store the next node
Reverse the direction of each link

children.text: Reverse a singly linked list in-place and return the new head.
Must reverse in-place with O(1) extra space.
Iterate through the list, reversing the direction of each node's pointer.

top_code.RUBY:
# Definition for singly-linked list.
class ListNode
    attr_accessor :val, :next
    def initialize(val = 0, _next = nil)
        @val = val
        @next = _next
    end
end

# Helper function to create linked list from array
def create_linked_list(arr)
    return nil if arr.empty?
    head = ListNode.new(arr[0])
    current = head
    (1...arr.length).each do |i|
        current.next = ListNode.new(arr[i])
        current = current.next
    end
    head
end

# Helper function to convert linked list to array
def linked_list_to_array(head)
    result = []
    current = head
    while current
        result << current.val
        current = current.next
    end
    result
end
top_code.PYTHON:
import sys

# Definition for singly-linked list.
class ListNode:
    def __init__(self, val=0, next=None):
        self.val = val
        self.next = next

# Helper function to create linked list from array
def create_linked_list(arr):
    if not arr:
        return None
    head = ListNode(arr[0])
    current = head
    for i in range(1, len(arr)):
        current.next = ListNode(arr[i])
        current = current.next
    return head

# Helper function to convert linked list to array
def linked_list_to_array(head):
    result = []
    current = head
    while current:
        result.append(current.val)
        current = current.next
    return result

title: 6. Valid Parentheses

children.text: , determine if the input string is valid.
Open brackets are closed by the same type of brackets.
Open brackets are closed in the correct order.

starter_code.RUBY:
def is_valid(s)
  # Write your solution here
  false
end

solution.RUBY:
def is_valid(s)
  stack = []
  mapping = {')' => '(', '}' => '{', ']' => '['}
  
  s.each_char do |char|
    if mapping.key?(char)
      top = stack.pop || '#'
      return false if mapping[char] != top
    else
      stack.push(char)
    end
  end
  
  stack.empty?
end

When you encounter a closing bracket, check if it matches the most recent opening bracket

Use a stack to keep track of open brackets. Match each closing bracket with the top of the stack.
Push open brackets onto the stack. For each closing bracket, check if it matches the top of the stack. If not, return false.
if not stack or stack[-1] != mapping[char]:
Track open brackets and match with closing

title: 8. Palindrome Number

children.text: An integer is a palindrome when it reads the same backward as forward.
Explanation: 121 reads as 121 from left to right and from right to left.
Explanation: From left to right, it reads -121. From right to left, it becomes 121-. Not a palindrome.

starter_code.RUBY:
def is_palindrome(x)
  # Write your solution here
  false
end

solution.RUBY:
def is_palindrome(x)
  # Negative numbers are not palindromes
  return false if x < 0
  
  # Single digit numbers are palindromes
  return true if x < 10
  
  # Numbers ending with 0 are not palindromes (except 0 itself)
  return false if x % 10 == 0 && x != 0
  
  reversed = 0
  while x > reversed
    reversed = reversed * 10 + x % 10
    x /= 10
  end
  
  # When the length is odd, we need to get rid of the middle digit
  x == reversed || x == reversed / 10
end

hints: Could you solve it without converting the integer to a string?
Try reversing the digits of the number
Be careful with negative numbers and numbers ending with 0

children.text: Check if an integer reads the same forward and backward.
No extra space for string conversion (optimal solution).
Reverse half of the number and compare with the other half.
Iteratively build the reversed number from the last digits and compare with the remaining part.
return x == rev or x == rev // 10
Numbers ending with zero (except zero itself)
Reverse half the digits and compare

title: 5. Binary Search

children.text: Given a sorted array of integers
, return the index if the target is found. If not, return
You must write an algorithm with
Explanation: 2 does not exist in nums.
nums is sorted in ascending order.
All values in nums are unique.

starter_code.RUBY:
def binary_search(nums, target)
  # Write your solution here
  -1
end

solution.RUBY:
def binary_search(nums, target)
  left = 0
  right = nums.length - 1
  
  while left <= right
    mid = (left + right) / 2
    if nums[mid] == target
      return mid
    elsif nums[mid] < target
      left = mid + 1
    else
      right = mid - 1
    end
  end
  
  -1
end

hints: Use two pointers to track the search range
Compare the middle element with the target in each iteration

children.text: Search for a target value in a sorted array using binary search.
Binary search repeatedly divides the array in half to locate the target efficiently.
pointers at the ends of the array. Check the middle element. If it matches, return its index. If target is less, search left half; if more, search right half.
Target at first or last index
Divide and conquer on sorted array
Halve the search space each step

starter_code.RUBY:
def length_of_longest_substring(s)
  map = {}
  left = 0
  max_len = 0
  
  s.chars.each_with_index do |c, right|
    if map[c] && map[c] >= left
      left = map[c] + 1
    end
    map[c] = right
    max_len = [max_len, right - left + 1].max
  end
  
  max_len
end

solution.RUBY:
def length_of_longest_substring(s)
  map = {}
  left = 0
  max_len = 0
  
  s.chars.each_with_index do |c, right|
    if map[c] && map[c] >= left
      left = map[c] + 1
    end
    map[c] = right
    max_len = [max_len, right - left + 1].max
  end
  
  max_len
end

title: 14. Rotate Array

children.text: , rotate the array to the right by
steps. Try to solve it in-place with O(1) extra space.

solution.RUBY:
def rotate(nums, k)
  n = nums.length
  return if n == 0
  
  k = k % n
  
  # Reverse the entire array
  nums.reverse!
  
  # Reverse the first k elements
  nums[0...k] = nums[0...k].reverse
  
  # Reverse the remaining elements
  nums[k..-1] = nums[k..-1].reverse
end
solution.PYTHON:
def rotate(nums, k):
    n = len(nums)
    k = k % n
    
    # Reverse the entire array
    nums.reverse()
    
    # Reverse the first k elements
    nums[:k] = nums[:k][::-1]
    
    # Reverse the remaining elements
    nums[k:] = nums[k:][::-1]

hints: The easiest solution would use additional memory and that is perfectly fine.
The actual trick comes when trying to solve this problem without using any extra space. This means you need to use the original array somehow to move the elements around.
Try using cyclic replacements.
Another approach is to reverse the array (or parts of it) to obtain the desired result.

children.text: Rotate an array to the right by k steps. The rotation should be done in-place with constant extra space.
The optimal solution uses array reversal. First, reverse the entire array. Then, reverse the first k elements, and finally reverse the remaining n - k elements.
Reverse the whole array, then reverse the first k and last n-k elements

title: 12. Fibonacci Number

children.text: The Fibonacci sequence is defined as follows: F(0) = 0, F(1) = 1, and F(n) = F(n-1) + F(n-2) for n > 1. Given

starter_code.RUBY:
def fibonacci(n)
  # Write your solution here
  0
end

solution.RUBY:
def fibonacci(n)
  return n if n <= 1
  
  dp = Array.new(n + 1)
  dp[0] = 0
  dp[1] = 1
  
  (2..n).each do |i|
    dp[i] = dp[i - 1] + dp[i - 2]
  end
  
  dp[n]
end

hints: Use an array or map to store previously calculated Fibonacci numbers
Consider using a bottom-up approach to avoid stack overflow for large n
Be careful about integer overflow for large values of n

Start from the base cases and build up to n by summing the previous two numbers.
Build up from base cases using two variables
Only previous two values are needed at each step

starter_code.RUBY:
def find_median_sorted_arrays(nums1, nums2)
  # Write your solution here
  0
end

solution.RUBY:
def find_median_sorted_arrays(nums1, nums2)
  # Ensure nums1 is the smaller array
  nums1, nums2 = nums2, nums1 if nums1.length > nums2.length
  
  x, y = nums1.length, nums2.length
  low, high = 0, x
  
  while low <= high
    partition_x = (low + high) / 2
    partition_y = (x + y + 1) / 2 - partition_x
    
    max_x = partition_x == 0 ? -Float::INFINITY : nums1[partition_x - 1]
    max_y = partition_y == 0 ? -Float::INFINITY : nums2[partition_y - 1]
    
    min_x = partition_x == x ? Float::INFINITY : nums1[partition_x]
    min_y = partition_y == y ? Float::INFINITY : nums2[partition_y]
    
    if max_x <= min_y && max_y <= min_x
      if (x + y) % 2 == 0
        return ([max_x, max_y].max + [min_x, min_y].min) / 2.0
      else
        return [max_x, max_y].max
      end
    elsif max_x > min_y
      high = partition_x - 1
    else
      low = partition_x + 1
    end
  end
  
  0.0
end

The key insight is to find the right partition point in both arrays
Use binary search on the smaller array to find the partition point

title: 11. Bubble Sort

children.text: Bubble Sort is a simple sorting algorithm that repeatedly steps through the array, compares adjacent elements, and swaps them if they are in the wrong order. This process is repeated until the array is sorted. After each pass, the largest unsorted element 'bubbles up' to its correct position at the end of the array. Bubble Sort works in-place and is stable, but is not efficient for large datasets.
, sort it in ascending order using Bubble Sort.
Explanation: An array that is already sorted should remain unchanged after applying bubble sort.

starter_code.RUBY:
def bubble_sort(arr)
  # Write your solution here
  arr
end

solution.RUBY:
def bubble_sort(arr)
  n = arr.length
  
  for i in 0...n
    swapped = false
    
    for j in 0...(n-i-1)
      if arr[j] > arr[j+1]
        # Swap arr[j] and arr[j+1]
        arr[j], arr[j+1] = arr[j+1], arr[j]
        swapped = true
      end
    end
    
    # If no swapping occurred in this pass, array is sorted
    break unless swapped
  end
  
  arr
end

hints: Compare adjacent elements and swap them if they are in the wrong order
After each pass, the largest element will be at the end of the array
Keep track of whether any swaps were made in a pass to optimize the algorithm

for j in range(0, n - i - 1):
Explanation: An array that is already sorted should remain unchanged after applying bubble sort.
Repeatedly swap adjacent elements if out of order
Largest elements bubble to the end each pass

title: 10. N-Queens

children.text: The n-queens puzzle asks you to place
chessboard so that no two queens threaten each other (no two queens share the same row, column, or diagonal).
Return all distinct solutions. Each solution is a list of

starter_code.RUBY:
def solve_n_queens(n)
  # Write your solution here
  []
end

solution.RUBY:
def solve_n_queens(n)
  result = []
  board = Array.new(n) { Array.new(n, '.') }
  
  def is_valid(board, row, col)
    # Check column
    (0...row).each do |i|
      return false if board[i][col] == 'Q'
    end
    
    # Check upper left diagonal
    i, j = row - 1, col - 1
    while i >= 0 && j >= 0
      return false if board[i][j] == 'Q'
      i -= 1
      j -= 1
    end
    
    # Check upper right diagonal
    i, j = row - 1, col + 1
    while i >= 0 && j < board.length
      return false if board[i][j] == 'Q'
      i -= 1
      j += 1
    end
    
    true
  end
  
  def backtrack(board, row, result)
    if row == board.length
      result << board.map(&:join)
      return
    end
    
    (0...board.length).each do |col|
      if is_valid(board, row, col)
        board[row][col] = 'Q'
        backtrack(board, row + 1, result)
        board[row][col] = '.'
      end
    end
  end
  
  backtrack(board, 0, result)
  result
end

hints: Use backtracking to explore all valid board configurations
For each position, check if placing a queen would conflict with any previously placed queens
Queens can attack horizontally, vertically, and diagonally

children.text: Place n queens on an n x n chessboard so that no two queens threaten each other. Return all possible board configurations.
No two queens can share the same row, column, or diagonal.
Use backtracking to try placing a queen in each row, checking for conflicts in columns and diagonals.
Recursively place queens row by row, using sets to track columns and diagonals. If a placement is valid, continue; otherwise, backtrack.
if c in cols or (r-c) in diag1 or (r+c) in diag2:
Try all placements row by row, backtrack on conflicts
Track columns and diagonals for conflicts

title: 13. Number of Islands

children.text: representing a map of '1's (land) and '0's (water), return the number of islands. An island is formed by connecting adjacent lands horizontally or vertically. All four edges of the grid are surrounded by water.

starter_code.RUBY:
def num_islands(grid)
  # Write your solution here
  0
end

solution.RUBY:
def num_islands(grid)
  return 0 if grid.empty? || grid[0].empty?
  
  rows, cols = grid.length, grid[0].length
  count = 0
  
  def dfs(grid, r, c)
    rows, cols = grid.length, grid[0].length
    
    # Check boundaries and if current cell is land
    return if r < 0 || c < 0 || r >= rows || c >= cols || grid[r][c] == '0'
    
    # Mark as visited
    grid[r][c] = '0'
    
    # Explore all 4 directions
    dfs(grid, r + 1, c)
    dfs(grid, r - 1, c)
    dfs(grid, r, c + 1)
    dfs(grid, r, c - 1)
  end
  
  (0...rows).each do |r|
    (0...cols).each do |c|
      if grid[r][c] == '1'
        count += 1
        dfs(grid, r, c)
      end
    end
  end
  
  count
end

hints: Use DFS or BFS to explore and mark all connected land cells
Remember to mark visited cells to avoid counting the same island multiple times
Consider the four directions (up, down, left, right) when exploring adjacent cells

children.text: Count the number of islands in a grid by marking visited land cells using DFS or BFS.
Traverse the grid; when a '1' is found, perform DFS/BFS to mark all connected land as visited.
if r < 0 or c < 0 or r >= m or c >= n or grid[r][c] != '1': return
Mark all connected land as visited for each island
